awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This award is made as part of the FY 2022 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Lena Ji is "Structure of algebraic varieties over arbitrary fields". The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Mircea Mustata.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Algebraic varieties are geometric objects defined by the vanishing of a finite set of (multivariable) polynomial equations. The polynomials have coefficients in some field k (for example, the rational numbers, the real numbers, or a finite field Fq), and the corresponding variety is defined over this field. Classically, algebraic varieties have been studied the most over the complex numbers. The goal of this project was to study various aspects of algebraic varieties defined over arbitrary fields. To this end, the project obtained results in several directions of research, described below.

A variety is said to be rational if it has a dense open set with a one-to-one parametrization by a dense open subset of affine space. For example, the variety x2+y2-z2=0 is rational via the stereographic projection from the point [0:1:1]. It is a classical question to determine whether a given variety is rational. Over the complex numbers, geometric properties (e.g., holomorphic forms) can sometimes be used to show that a given variety is not rational. For varieties defined over fields that are not algebraically closed, the arithmetic of the field comes into play as well. For example, a smooth projective variety that is rational over a field k necessarily has a k-rational point. This shows that the real variety defined by x2+y2+z2=0 is not R-rational.

For curves and surfaces, the rationality question over non-closed fields is understood. However, starting in dimension 3, the picture is much less clear. In joint work with S. Frei, S. Sankar, B. Viray, and I. Vogt, the PI has studied the rationality question for threefolds over non-closed fields and has made progress for a certain class of threefolds with an additional fibration structure. With F. Suzuki, the PI has also studied the rationality question for a certain class of higher-dimensional varieties relating to pencils of quadrics.

This project has also yielded several results about the structure of varieties over the complex numbers, in particular, for Fano varieties. Fano varieties form one of the three building varieties for varieties, and they are "close" to rational varieties; for example, they contain many rational curves. Some examples of Fano varieties are given by low degree hypersurfaces (varieties defined by a single polynomial equation). In certain degree ranges, very general Fano hypersurfaces are known to be irrational by work of Koll\'ar, Totaro, and Schreieder. In joint work with N. Chen, B. Church, and D. Stapleton, for a subrange of these Fano hypersurfaces, the PI has shown "how irrational" these varieties are by studying a certain measure of irrationality.

Other aspects of complex Fano varieties were also studied during the project. In a joint paper with L. Esser and J. Moraga, the PI studied the action of the symmetric group on Fano varieties and the geometric consequence of such an action. This question is related to the essential dimension of Sn, which relates to classical problems about simplifying polynomials via Tschirnhaus transformations. Finally, another problem studied during the project was the behavior of the structure of Fano varieties in families. In joint work with K. DeVleming, P. Kennedy-Hunt, and M. Quek, the PI determined the K-moduli compactification of the moduli space of a 6-dimensional family of Fano threefolds, and studied the behavior of certain fibration structures of the boundary of the moduli space.

During the period of the project, the PI has mentored undergraduate and graduate students, has (co-)organized learning seminars and an algebraic geometry workshop, and has served on the leadership of the Association for Women in Mathematics Michigan Student Chapter. The results of this project have been posted publicly on arXiv.org, and links to the published versions of papers from the project can be found on the PI's webpage. The PI has also given numerous research talks to further disseminate the results from this project at seminars and conferences in the United States, Canada, Europe, and Asia.
